Starship is heavy and a large heat shield is required to recover …just empty tanks and a cargo bay. Therefore, for a small crew orbital fully reusable commuter system, I suggest that landing a DreamChaser type lifting body can be a lot safer for regular crew orbital missions (no parachutes no back thrust multi re-ignitions, etc). This 3 stages system proposed, providing existing technologies could be consolidated by NASA from different co. currently competing and legally conflicting, would be to use Paul Allen Stratolaunch huge plane with 220 tons lift as stage one, then a small Falcon heavy central stage type recovered far at sea as second stage and finally the DreamChaser fitted with two orbital and reignited engines Merlin or equivalent with all valving, COPV header tanks inside the vehicle, recovered and saved with the landing DreamChaser like for the shuttle with most fuel supplied by two or four side mounted drop tanks, 3D printed and as third stage power only therefore quite small. Three stages are this way lighter and almost 100 % rapidly reusable while using synergies of those existing systems. The small 2 or 4 drop tanks ejected just before reaching orbit and burning down do not carry any heat shield for recovery and this is a big weight saving gain like the stratospheric lift plane as well. The lifting body design is also much safer for crew than fragiles winged shuttle and other landing systems but would be slightly beefed up to hold and recover also the orbital propulsion and life support systems currently wasted by Falcon 9 second stage and crew dragon service module. Note second stage could also consist of an oversized Pegasus winged initial stage rocket recovered like a gliding drone once empty and light..but this requires more development and maybe more dead weight also than a Falcon 9 recovery representing about a 16% of capacity penalty ..but the rocket wing can contribute to plane take off lift and increases this way the possible take off weight in theory…maybe up to 240 or 250 tons..as a hanging large Pegasus pushing a DreamChaser load…

This may be off topic, but someone might find it interesting.
Over unity electric generator. By AMA.
Segment 1: 1 motor with bar connected to it standing vertically. Circular disc connected to bar that has magnets embedded in it surrounded in high permeability material to focus magnets outward pushing force in an upwards direction from top of disc.
Segment 2: Hollowed out cylindrical Bar of material horizontally positioned.
Flat hollowed out ring shaped material with openings around its outer top flat edge.
Magnets surrounded in high permeability material embedded in these openings.
Magnets positioned in openings around ring are in at least 1 of 2 configurations either all N magnetic field pushing out or N,S,N,S all around it. Just depends on whether your going for Piston structure or spinning structure explained below & whether you want it to be DC or AC current.
Place these all along the cylindrical bar connected to it solidly, except at far ends of bar.
At both ends of bar place ring of material that can be magnetically repelled in specific locations. (magnetically repelled in specific location is in reference to outside of ring area that faces away from center of bar)(Other side of same ring facing in towards center of bar is capable of being magnetically repelled all around) Ring must be connected solidly to bar. points of repulsion on these rings is off set from each other on each end of bar.
3 Hollow ring structures with small square bars protruding from each. Ring structure has all magnetic repulsion on inside of ring shape & can rap around the main bar so that the bar wont be causing friction on things as it moves back and forth or spins. 1st positioned around far left of bar, 2nd position at center of bar (be sure to leave enough room for magnetic structures to be able to move back and forth without hitting it) & 3rd positioned on far right of bar.
Tube structure is constructed in two parts that fit together on top of each other length wise over main structure.
Tube structure has 3 square openings for the bars that the Ring structures that are connected around the main bar keeping it from causing friction on structure, to slide into.
This tube structure is designed with material that does not block magnetic fields. Perhaps some type of transparent material glass or other.
At both ends of the tube structure there is a built in circular groove that will house a round disc. The ceiling/floor/left side/& right side of groove has openings for small magnets to be embedded in it, so that the pushing force from magnets is pushing in towards the edge of disc that goes in this spot. There is also 4 openings located on the top, bottom, left & right positions of the open groove. Small magnets are placed in these spots so when round disc is in position these magnetic fields will hit sideways keeping it from generating friction against structure.
Far Ends of bar has Cap structure that screws over tube halves holding them together. Cap structure also has 4 points on inside top, bottom, left & right that have openings. These openings have small embedded magnets in them that exert there pushing force outwards (sideways) so it will keep disc in position, generating no friction against structure. Cap is made of material like tube so it does not block magnetic fields. (Note: These magnets in groove and cap structure are only needed for piston design. If Disc is directly connected to main bar so as it spins the bar spins, magnets are not needed here).
The disc has ring around it (ring of material goes around outer edge and folds over front side & backside a small distance) that is repelled by magnetic fields so the 12 small magnets will keep it lined up but it will be able to spin without causing friction on structure. The disc has openings on it's flat side that face inside of tube and magnets surrounded in high permeability material are embedded in this disc.
The disc has small bar that is connected to it's center that goes all the way to the other end of bar structure through the center of the hollowed out bar and connects to disc on other end. Disc on other end is set up the same but magnets embedded in it are off set in comparison. As first disc spins the magnetic fields will push against specific spot on disc connected directly to bar, pushing bar in other direction, once bar is fully pushed over, further spinning of disc will then align the other sides magnet to push it back.
Tube structure also has half moon shaped protrusion on inside and on both halves so when tube is connected they line up to make a full ring shape on inside of tube, these half moon shaped protrusions have at least 1 small round opening on it's side in middle of curve that faces away from center of bar. The opening has a small magnet embedded in it so magnetic force is repelling out sideways away from center of bar. The protruding ring is positioned to line up slightly further in towards center of bar then the ring of magnetically repelled material connected directly to bar. This way when bar moves right or left it is magnetically stopped after a short distance.
Copper coil setup: Copper coils are wound in at least 1 of 2 ways. Either coiled in circles next to each other (Like if you wound coils around a cylindrical bar) or laid out in a row as if wire was on flat table going up then bent to go down & back up until it formed a flat rectangle of wire bending up and down and then the entire structure folded around tube. Copper windings are then lined up perpendicular to magnetic fields on outside of tube. Ends of copper coils are connected into separate construct that will allow electrical current to flow somewhere else.
Circular construct is built like a stand that goes around the outside of motor segment. Circular construct has flat ring of high permeability (magnetic field shielding) material that has small openings that will allow magnetic fields through specific locations. Top of circular construct has groove to allow the horizontal bar to balance on. Circular construct can also be placed on other end of bar so it is balanced. The motor segment is positioned so the disc connected to the bar that is connected to the motor is lined up so the disc passes under the horizontal bars disc that is at end of horizontal bar. The high permeability material keeps the magnetic fields in disc from hitting into the disc that spins or pushes the horizontal bar until just the right moment when the impact will cause the disc in horizontal bar to spin which will perpetuate the piston motion in the horizontal bar. More horizontal bars of the same design are built and positioned around the motor segment in a circular horizontal fashion all the way around. The bar connected to the motor can be increased in length to desired height (As much as motor can handle) and more of the exact same setup is repeated higher and higher up, maximizing the over unity potential of the construct to ridiculous proportions. :D Current from the horizontal bars is diverted to power the motor as needed and all other current is diverted to power my game console or the world. :) Interesting variation to this design would be to connect the spinning discs on far ends of horizontal bar to main bar that magnets are connected to so the magnets spin instead of getting pistoned back and forth. So long as moving magnetic fields are perpendicular to copper wires it should work. By AMA

SpaceX me fait rêver, comme quand j’avais 8 ans (en 1969) et que mon frère aîné m’expliquer tout de Apollo... Nuit blanche pour voir en direct le premier pas, une carte de la lune sur la table, la maquette du LEM au point d’atterrissage prévu... Whaouh, quels souvenirs !
Et après, plus rien, trop cher, trop compliqué, la crise du pétrole, et le Concorde aussi devenu trop gourmand, plus rien pour faire rêver aux avions et aux étoiles...
Et là maintenant, plein d’enthousiasme à regarder Starship. Déjà, les 1er étage de Falcon9 qui reviennent, comme si de rien n’était, je ne me lasse pas. Et là, voir ce vaisseau faire son belly-flop, comme dans un rêve, mais non, on n’est pas dans un film de Flash Gordon ! C’est pour de vrai !
Vivement que la grande joie donnée pendant un moment par SN10 se renouvelle. Et là je pense à « Tintin » et sa « Conquête de la Lune », oui, pour de vrai, voir ces gros bidules rutilants se poser comme un charme, re-croire à la conquête de l’espace, vivement ! Oui !

(PS : Et le programme Artemis prend une toute autre envergure avec Starship aussi !!!)

SpaceX makes me dream, like when I was 8 years old (in 1969) and my older brother explained to me everything about Apollo ... Sleepless night to see the first step live, a map of the moon on the table, the model of the LEM at the planned landing point ... Whaouh, what memories!
And after, nothing, too expensive, too complicated, the oil crisis, and the Concorde also became too greedy, nothing to make the planes and the stars dream ...
And right now, full of excitement watching Starship. Already, the 1st stage of Falcon9 coming back, as if nothing had happened, I can't get enough of it. And there, to see this ship do its belly-flop, like in a dream, but no, this is not a Flash Gordon movie! This is for real!
I can't wait for the great joy given for a while by SN10 to be renewed. And there I am thinking of "Tintin" and his "Conquest of the Moon", yes, for real, seeing these big shiny gadgets posing like a charm, re-believing in the conquest of space, strongly! Yes !

(PS: And the Artemis program takes a whole new dimension with Starship too !!!)

A stripped-down Cargo Starship, packed with multiple sensor suites, will embark for Mars in 2024. It will be primarily a fact-finding mission, measuring every aspect of Starship performance over the 6 month duration mission. All the data will be beamed back to Earth for immediate and extensive analysis, and will likely result in changes made to Starship for future missions to Mars. The vessel's return to Earth will have to wait for the next departure window.

The trips to the moon will be fairly straight forward by comparison. This year, 2021, will see multiple Starship test flights to Earth orbit, and perhaps the first crewed flight to orbit. In 2022 it's likely several lunar uncrewed Starship flights will launch to the moon, orbit, land, and return. And then late next year the first crewed Starship lunar mission will launch. It's unlikely SpaceX's bid to join Artemis will happen, and thus Starship can be launched without that NASA distraction slowing down their progress.

The space tourism Starship mission to the moon with the Japanese guest will likely occur in 2023. Also in 2023 the fuel transfer capability in Earth orbit will be completed.

There will also be 2 other uncrewed missions to Mars launched in that brief 2024 window, with slight design variations to test in situ in Mars orbit and on the surface.

This in 2026, building on everything learned from the 2024 Mars launches, several Starships will be launched to Mars, 1 or 2 crewed, the others as Cargo versions.

I get the sense Elon will move aggressively and rapidly once the reusable and fully reliable Starship is a reality, which seems 99% certain now.

Top notch video and well appreciated. As for speculations I have for future development, here you go:
1. SpaceX is already using solar electric propulsion for Starlink. As most of what you ship to the moon is fuel to push more fuel around and SpaceX has already proposed landing a massive Starship on the moon, which is going to take a lot more fuel than what can be loaded onto a single Starship in LEO, especially for reuse, I think they will use a solar electric space tug launched on on Starship to push tanker Starships out to the moon. The ISP on these solar electric drives already exceed 4,000s of ISP where Raptor vacuum gets up to 350s, so even with the extra mass of a space tug and the loss of using the Oberth Effect, it would be far more efficient and require far fewer launches than to LOX/LNG the whole way. Elon Musk has stated Starship should have very little fuel boil off on the way to Mars, so why would there be an issue spending say several weeks slowly pushing a tanker to the moon? I am thinking this could also be done for cargo only missions, except using a cargo Starship instead of a tanker Starship. The reason for pushing a tanker Starship to the moon would only be so a crewed mission could happen rapidly instead of at the slow pace of a solar powered ion drive in the Earth-Moon system.

2. Something cool about the cargo space tug idea when applied to Mars is while the space tugs will produce a lot less thrust around Mars, with cargo you mainly have to eventually get the job done. Also a space tug could separate from a cargo Starship before entering Mar's orbit and start its capture burn while the cargo Starship continues to the surface or swing by Mars and go back to Earth. Once the space tug gets into a highly elliptical capture orbit, it could circularize with its large delta-V potential and say get into a low Mars or low Earth orbit. The cargo Starships sent out to Mars could either be optimized with small fuel tanks designed to get an empty Starship into LEO and then once refueled and loaded with cargo, land the maximum amount of cargo on Mars in a one way mission or be a more generic cargo ship with some hardware for unloading on Mars and be able to fly back to an orbiting space tug to be brought back to Earth. Having a space tug with over 4,000s of ISP capability really expands the possibilities of what can be done for cargo missions, granted it just takes too long to speed up to be the primary mover on crewed missions.

3. I think the first generation of 'safe' crewed transport to Mars will involve building large scale nuclear thermal propulsed spaceships as that will get you up to ~1,000s of ISP, which really changes the dynamic of how a Mars mission could go while having enough thrust to do things quickly with either nuclear electric or solar electric drives to help speed along the 'coast' phase of the mission. Once we are gathering material from the moon, an important overlooked material is nuclear fuel. If you gather the nuclear fuel from the moon, you avoid a lot of fallout from trying to ship that nuclear fuel up from Earth with hopefully controlled explosions into space and the controversy attempting such a thing would cause. You really can't do a safe crewed mission to Mars without nuclear power shipped to the surface of Mars as one dust storm covering your solar panels and your crew dies, so it makes sense to extend this nuclear power into making the trip to Mars in the first place faster and safer as well as more comfortable. One reason why you need to go big with a crewed mission is surface area to protect from radiation is a square factor where volume covered by that shielding is a cubic factor. So as you go bigger, that shielding goes from being too heavy to eventually being a relatively trivial part of your space ship mass wise. There is a second thing where task optimized Starships are going to be a lot more effective at their job than jack of all trades Starships. So you do a jack of all trades Starship to Mars, maybe you stick 10 people on a one way mission to Mars and the Starship is loaded up with shielding and provisions and space to move around and equipment for once you get to Mars, etc. Also maybe some crews can handle the isolation and some crews go nuts and space each other on the way to Mars. However have a fleet of task optimized Starships riding on a mother ship to Mars allowing for tight coordination and your crewed lander Starship carries 100 or more people airliner fashion to the surface and then flies back up to refuel and carry another 100 or more people to the surface. A large ship means you can have thousands of people onboard and lots of space to move around, which is a lot easier to cope with than say 10 people trapped in a tin can for a long duration mission. Having a large ship also provides more room for trying out artificial gravity, though would think the artificial gravity experiments would be done in LEO first to determine what exactly would need to be done for this large ship going to Mars. Also such a large ship would always be in space and so would be optimized for a permanent space environment going between the Earth and Mars cruise liner style where Starship could then be left to focus on being a short haul airliner of sorts. If a good nuclear fission propulsion system could be achieved where maybe low to no fallout fuel is used around Earth while avoiding big flashes that could harm satellites in orbit (or even blind people looking up) and then you do whatever is cheapest a safe distance away from Earth, the efficiency gained in propulsion could allow very fast trips to anywhere in the solar system. So far with our fusion work we tend to go big to get the economies of scale to make it work and be more practical, so a large dedicated ship for this makes a lot of sense.

Chemical rockets just cannot do such a job of going to and from Mars because the ISP is not there and so say a Mars mission is a one way mission with it being rather impractical to in-situ manufacture the large amount of fuel needed to send say a 9m wide Starship back. Nuclear thermal exponentially improves the equation to it at least being somewhat practical, though still somewhat expensive to go back and forth between Earth and Mars, but a lot cheaper, faster, safer, and more comfortable than doing chemical only. Ion drives makes it a lot cheaper to move cargo and fuel around and this is important because fuel tends to get a lot more expensive the further out from Earth you are, at least until you figure out a system of getting it from the solar system, which we are way far from doing in a practical manner right now, granted it should be doable one day with the right setup. Direct nuclear propulsion can really open up the solar system, though some thoughtfulness needs to go into the safest designs possible, especially when operating around Earth, which is really important because literally no humans live beyond LEO right now and at that the current count in LEO is 7. So if it is not safe to use that drive in LEO, another drive system will be needed to get to a safe distance away from Earth, but this leg of your journey is a huge part of your battle for basically every mission, so your drive system really needs to try to solve this problem if it can be done.

So, I know this is a bit cheap now since it's already happened, but I was always amused at how everyone was talking about how hard the "flip manoeuvre" was going to be. Everyone seemed to forget that the Starship has these humungous control surfaces on it, which are placed at the extreme ends of the vehicle, those surfaces will have an enormous amount of control authority, and probably, I would suspect, would be completely able to right the ship to upright even without the engines or cold-gas thrusters fairly quickly. My concern was always more about whether they would be able to keep the pressure to the engine during the manoeuvre which did turn out to be the issue (although admittedly I assumed the relight would occur during the reorientation so I was imagining problems with the relight itself). People should stop worrying so much about the aerodynamic stuff though, this is well understood at this point, and the rocket isn't really that complicated as a controllable object. The only issues it might have with controllability will come at high mach numbers where they will have the cold gas thrusters anyway/.

A point I've made before for other superb videos you've made is that the cost of a fully reusable rocket is comprised of four factors, not only the two you list. Cost per launch is calculated as cost of (fuel) +  (other mission expenses like refurbishing, ground personnel etc.) + (cost of manufacture / total number of flights per vehicle) + (cost of vehicle development / total number of flights of all vehicles of the same design).  Your video lists only the first two and so grossly underestimates actual cost per flight.  Yup it will be cheaper by far than a ULA, but still considerably more than just the first to factors.

45:20 re:"To slow down w' rockets you need to use as much energy as to launch it." That part is not quite true tho. The rocket's initial launch power was used to accelerate BOTH stages, as well as the 2nd stage's FULL LOAD OF FUEL.
When slowing down tho, the lonely 2nd stage weighs much less than the original combined 1st & 2nd stage, and also that 2nd stage will not be fully fueled anymore - so it weighs a lot less again. It requires much less energy to slow it down.

As usual, excellent video. One of the questions you asked an opinion on is do we think we'll make it to Mars using Starship. Elon is an impatient and brilliant guy. If he wasn't, this would take 10 times as long, as it has in the past. That being said, his optimism on timeline are kind of crazy. I am sure that the Starship hardware could get things to Mars in the next few years, but that is only one small part of a successful Mars colonization effort. Also, Dr Zubrin of Mars Direct fame has calculated that refueling a Starship on Mars to return to Earth would either take incredibly massive power, (more solar panels than you could even fit on many Starships or maybe a high energy nuclear reactor power system), or a lot more time than the distance between Mars launch windows, because Starship's mass and therefore propellant tanks are so large. He has a plan (see The Angry Astronaut, your Bizarro World counterpart) involving a Mini-Starship launched as payload on a conventional Starship as kind of a second stage for a much smaller crew to make it to Mars.
Also there are the multitude of technological issues of keeping the colonists ALIVE to reach Mars, and keep them alive once they get there, radiation being one of the prime issues, as well as the effects of microgravity. Unfortunately, we don't seem to have equally impatient geniuses working on those problems, and Elon doesn't seem to be addressing them. (Let's face it, he has his hands full developing Starship as you have shown in this video.) So I hope we will get to Mars, but I don't think we will do it nearly as fast as Elon hopes. If we kept to his timeline, I expect we would have a lot of either debilitated or dead colonists, which might not be the best political move for keeping the effort alive. On a more optimistic note, NASA appears to be generating some effort to research artificial magnetospheres for Mars or other planets. This seems to me to be the best solution to radiation protection on board spacecraft, as well as a larger version on board a Martian satellite to shield Mars atmosphere from Solar Wind erosion. The article I saw said that if Mars atmosphere was shielded, natural processes on the Red Planet would thicken the atmosphere over time on its own! Wouldn't that be cool.

Somewhat altruistic and "Green" but also a big win in the areas of the reduction of "collateral damage:" for future space flight. A simple Bolt in orbit can wreak havoc, imagine something as big as a Booster hitting anything in its never ending and uncontrollable orbital path, simply devastatingly destructive (which adds to "space trash" in orbit). Elon and Space X are true pioneers. That he can be so bold as to not loose too much sleep and say he is 33% the the launch today would not go right was perfect. The Starship clearly has a lot of space but comparing it to a 747 doesn't really work, I find.

On Starship re-entry one thing we often lose sight of, since it is very unintuitive, is that not all the energy being dissipated in the shock front is necessarily absorbed by the body of the re-entry vessel. What is initially encountering the stationary atmosphere is a leading edge of hypersonic accelerated compressed gas and plasma. This means that, just as you saw in the video of re-entry burns of the Falcon 9 booster, there is a boundary layer in advance of the body of the vehicle. But in that case the boundary layer itself will dissipate a lot of heat as radiant energy and carry even more around the vehicle in superheated air. The tiles also will shed heat as radiant energy- literally light, just like a light bulb. When this thing falls out of space it will be one heck of a light show.

So, I am not an engineer or a rocket scientist so take the following for what you think it is worth. I really think that the Starship has the wrong design with the recessed rockets inside the skirt of the rocket body. After seeing the damage that was caused by a prepared hardened surface under the launch mount (which is something like 25 or 30 feet above the surface, can you imagine the destruction that could happen when the Starship lands on  unprepared landing surface such as on Mars. SpaceX has already recognized that they will need upper thrusters for a moon landing due to the fact that the main rockets would just carve out a big hole where they want to land. I contend that this will be a problem for Mars as well and this presents lots of problems. For example, on the moon there is no aero braking and thus no need for the heat shield, wings and belly flop maneuver to slow down the craft and let it land. But on Mars this is not the case and the aero braking is definitely needed just like on Earth so if SpaceX intends to put the upper rockets on a Mars version, they would be difficult to place symmetrically on the ship without interfering with the heat shield and/or the aerodynamics during the aerobraking procedure. The gravity of Mars is also much much greater than the moon so the upper rockets would have to be larger than the moon version taking up more interior space and adding weight. If they don’t have these upper rockets on the Mars version, I just don’t see how the current engine within skirt design could survive the horrendous amount of rock and debris that would be thrown up by that sort of landing as the skirt would essentially catch all the flying objects and direct it around the engine bay. With the Falcon 9, the open design allows any debris to escape sideways and generally not upward and there is no skirt that could allow something to bounce around inside. Even so, the engines (other than the rocket cones) are protected with armour for both the boost back fire and landing debris. The Falcon 9 legs are very large relatively speaking compared to the Starship legs and contact the surface away from directly under the engine blast. If the Starship sticks with the skirt design, the engines will dug out a hole directly under the rocket right where it wants to plant its “feet”. Not a good plan. For the Earth, the skirt design would probably work because you could simply armour under the launch mount with steel plate and for landing you are most likely going to land on either a steel deck of a ship or an armoured landing pad. So this design might work for Earth where the facilities at the landing site are carefully prepared but on either the moon or Mars, I think you either need to have upper rockets doing the landing (taking up space and increasing weight), which might be hard with Mars’s gravity, or SpaceX will have to forget about the rockets under the skirt idea and expose the engines and armour the bottom of the engine bay, just like the Falcon 9. If they conclude this is the answer to the debris problem, then that will affect the aerodynamics of the belly re-entry maneuver and of course the little landing legs will be a no go. I think that the real Starship that makes it to either the moon or Mars, will look nothing like the “Earth” design that can land on prepared landing surfaces. Keep up the good work on your channel!

Regarding cancelling the velocity, you would need the same ∆v as it took to launch (- the ∆v savings of aerobraking). But you wouldn't need the same "rocket" to generate that ∆v.
For 2nd stage reentry, there's no weight of the 1st stage or the payload fairings or the payload. Less mass, less fuel.
With an overpowered Mvac as it is, I think a small powerful burn can cancel a lot of that velocity.
(Kind of how it takes 9 Merlin engines to launch a Falcon 9, but only 1 to cancel the velocity in the boostback burn - I guess that 1 engine maybe creates a ∆v double of the 9 engines to cancel the forward velocity and generate an equal reverse velocity to RTLS)

From a physics perspective, I think a good way of thinking about the energy that starship has to dissipate in reentry is that it should be the same amount of energy that was required to get it into orbit. Meaning except for the amount of energy it uses from the engines to slow down at the last second, it is similar to blasting those same rocket engines at the side of starship to transfer that equivalent amount of energy. One thing to note would be that starship may spend more or less time in reentry than liftoff, which would mean that if it spent twice as much time in reentry it would be like it was being blasted by the engines at half power for that duration. If it spends half the time in reentry, it would be like it is being blasted at 2x power. Since heat transfer is pretty consistent, it would experience virtually the same effect as a rocket engines blasting itself.

Just to clarify. There is one component of the reentry heating that goes with velocity to the power of 8. When the airflow hits the rocket the particles in the FoR of the rocket are moving at the rocket's speed. But they get pressed by the rocket from one side and by more air from the other side so this linear velocity that they have becomes the speed that gives them their heat energy (or you can think of it as their kinetic energy being directly converted into thermal energy due to the compression).

As you may know from thermodynamics the temperature of a gas is proportional to the kinetic energy (in the FoR of the gas) of the particles. So T ~ E ~ v^2. The air heats up the rocket either through conduction (the heat flow is proportional to the temperature difference which is approximately proportional to T ~ v^2) or through thermal radiation. The radiation is the stronger component at high velocities because the heat flow is proportional to T^4 (black body radiation) ~ v^8.

I am sorry I am late to the party. But I do have to respond to the question asked in the video, "Will Starship take humans to Mars?"

I do not think that this vehicle will be the vehicle that actually carry humans to Mars. I do definitely think it will be used to pre-stage the living environment for them. However, the actual human transport ship, while most probably built by Elon and SpaceX, and probably also carry some variation of the Starship moniker, will not be any of the variations mentioned in this video. That vehicle will have to:
1) Be much larger and therefore,
2) Be built or assemble in Earth orbit or L1 or L2 orbit or the moon.
3) Provide at least a constant .3G gravity in order to prevent incapacitating loss of bone and muscle tone while also acclimating the inhabitants to martian gravity.
4) Shield the inhabitants from X-Ray, gamma, and cosmic radiation.
5) Carry enough provisions for at least the extended 3 month mission. In fact, if I were in charge, I would double or triple that in case it is needed as a rescue ship for future missions.

I see a few factors dictating the scope of what SpaceX's Starship does verses where it may have a reduced supportive role / different solution to get to the end goal:
1. Cost per launch - This is a place where obviously Starship will take over, other rockets will be phased out, and where the current SLS (Space Launch System) will fail its mission even if NASA keeps throwing money at it.

2. Cost for a given delta-V - Starship will clearly dominate LEO to GTO here. Much beyond this, a more complex picture starts emerging as chemical rockets have their limit. Basically the further you go from Earth, the more costly your fuel gets and this factor tends to grow widely out of control, especially when you start talking about landing on and taking off from other large gravitational objects or even just doing a capture burn once getting to a destination (there is a reason we didn't stop at Pluto for example) and the delta-V required for deep space missions as you work against the Sun's gravity well and make those large trips in reasonable time scales and such. We have several other engine technologies besides chemical rockets and more we can achieve with some development work. While you may keep with chemical for long duration one way robotic missions and continue to see some ion drive style engines in use, if we ever move humans beyond the Earth-Moon system, it will likely use some form of nuclear tech to get the ISP high enough to quickly and more efficiently move humans around than chemical can do. This means you really want to use something besides Starship for the job just on delta-V based considerations alone as the cost to get even the minimum delta-V will be less with a different technology than what Starship uses. For example to go from LEO to LMO (Low Earth Orbit to Low Mars Orbit) with a given amount of payload, with Starship it will take at least 7 launches (one for Starship and 6 refueling runs) where with hauling up a nuclear thermal spaceship, maybe you initially do 4 launches (two flights to haul it up with some cargo onboard then a mixed cargo/fuel launch, then one more just for fuel) and cut it down moving forward with more optimizations. If you can get to a fairly clean burning fusion rocket design such as ICF fusion, the propellant tank on a ship like that would be more like that on your car to get to anywhere in the solar system because the ISP will be so high.

3. Economies of scale - Elon Musk has specifically talked about SpaceX's Starship being its size because it is the minimum size to get the job at hand done. The minimum size is also bound by other upper bound issues of making chemical rockets bigger that blast off from the surface of the Earth. So you never want to go smaller as for example the difficulties in recovering the second stage gets into the realm of having no payload capacity or even falling back to Earth without achieving orbit. But there would also be some major issues in trying to go all that much bigger, like what do you do about the noise / vibrations, being a safe distance from a launch site and finding such a suitable site, etc. Then for long duration human travel away from Earth you have to consider things like impactors at high speed and how you don't want all of the air to leak out from subsequent holes due to inadequate protection. With any impactor protection system it will largely boil down to surface area covered and unit of mass to adequately protect where volume of stuff in the ship behind this shield is a cubic equation. Also radiation shielding where there are some definite economies of scale issues where at the small scale the squared surface area to cover verses cubic volume protected makes it ridiculously heavy to have enough where at the very large scale it shrinks to a small part of the lugging mass around equation. SpaceX's Starship is in the realm of very cumbersome as in maybe the bulk of your mission weight is shielding and just a few humans are also there. So yeah, to have a well shielded and thus radiation / impactor wise safe mission, gotta go big, really big, or go home. Then for providing humans with artificial gravity via centripetal force, you need to go big, really big, or you will make your crew sick from the spinning motion. It is also kind of hard to say have two small, well shielded ships tethered together swinging around as you will have huge loads on the tether and thus a big, heavy tether to get the job done. Actually if you go big enough, you may think of having stationary shielding around say a rotating drum. Once you get to this point, you can have some good protections and more Earth like conditions on your ship to counter the main known physical problems with having people in space for long durations. On the more psychological side, a mission still fails if everyone spaces each other and then commits suicide. When a deep space mission like this fails, well there goes the funding for any future missions like it. So you really need a large crew with lots of space to move around on one ship so they have enough human interactions with enough different people and just room to explore and not feel trapped to stay reasonably sane and even happy. Anyways how often do you hear about people speaking highly about their highly confined prison experiences? Fo training, if you don't have to train an astronaut for years for a single mission as they have to do so much with so few people, but instead do things more like say an aircraft carrier where many people mainly just learn their niche position quickly and also send along other specialists to both be your AAA riding along with you (as you can't just call AAA when your spaceship breaks down in deep space) as well as mission specific specialists (like your science team, a problem with Apollo is only 1 scientist ever flew and he accomplished more useful science than all of the other astronauts combined). So yeah, especially when you get to sending humans on long duration space missions, I am thinking it is either going to be go big or go home. In these cases Starship could be your airliner and be pretty good at it, but something else is going to be your cruise liner of sorts for the long stay in space.

4. Reusability - So SpaceX's Starship gets you reusability when going to LEO. At this it is a fair amount of wear and tear to do with many engines to maintain on the first stage and huge forces / heat on the second stage literally wearing it away. When you go to the Moon with Starship, at least all of the proposed missions I have seen have used piles of tanks as in something like 27 tanker flights to get a single Starship to the Moon and back. Especially seeing each Starship should only get 3% of its starting mass as payload into orbit so 3% / 27 ~= .1%, that speaks more to being on the ragged edge or reusability, especially as that is a lot of wear and tear for all of those tanker flights. For the Martian landing, Elon Musk is talking about landing on fuel vapors after several in orbit refueling runs. Those few fuel vapors are not going to get you back to Earth as there is going to be nothing at all in the tank when Starship touches down. So then my calculations on getting enough equipment on the surface of Mars to get one Starship back to Earth every 2 years or so during the transfer window suggest somewhere on the order of 1,000 launches from Earth to pull off. That doesn't sound very practical. So yeah, you are quickly looking at if you don't absolutely have to fly back to Earth, all of those Starships are going to be expended once they reach their destination. When you get into more advanced drive systems to get around the solar system, you can quickly get into the realm of reusing a large ship. However some of these drive systems don't scale down too far, so again you start ending up with go big as in something much bigger than any rocket you would ever blast off from the surface of the Earth or go home.

It's the rapidly reusable that's got me stumped. We've all seen how slowly the spacecraft moves from one place to another. Would there be enough time to get that launcher to the launchpad on its first use? Would the required checks be made in the time available before the next orbit? Could the fuel load be completed in time for a full static fire before launch as is SpaceX' protocol? How quickly would the tanker be able to get back to the landing pad after it has finished transferring its fuel in orbit?

We've seen that if a launch window is missed, it's another nearly 24 hours before another launch window becomes available, yet the talk here seems to be launching the, currently, 4 tankers one after another. That doesn't square with what we've seen and heard.

Not wishing to seem to be macabre, but sending humans into space and back is a risky business. What will SpaceX do to ensure that surviving members of a family are provided for, in the event of a fatality?

Elon Musk is aiming for 48 launches next year. It would take 28 Starship launches to deploy the12000 Starlinks to provide a global internet connection. He'll provide a means to put 100-150 metric tonnes into LEO and reduced the cost to orbit and back to make the industrialisation of LEO conceivable, for the first time.

Personally, I highly doubt that "Starship" will ever be used for serious interplanetary transport. Much research is already being done into nuclear thermal, nuclear electric and solar electric propulsion. Those technologies are far more efficient than the chemical rocket engines that Starship uses , and in the case of nuclear thermal, similar thrust. My belief is that it will be used for similar purposes as the space shuttle in bring cargo and crew to and from orbit.

I'm sure starship will take the first humans and material to Mars (and the moon).

But eventually (I hope sooner rather than later) vertical take off and landing will be replaced by horizontal take off and landing.

It's a matter of energy storage/production and size. If you think Starship is big, the future will amaze you.

I envision transport ships that will go orbit to orbit, so big they have their own shuttles on board for surface to orbit and orbit to surface, (last mile) transport.

Science fiction?... Of course!

But so was Starship, 5 years ago.

So here's an interesting question that comes to mind with a lot of technologies, and these especially.

There's a thing I want to name the 'imagination penalty,' or maybe the 'cowardice penalty?' Something like that. Measured in time.

The question is, changing nothing else, how far back in time could this have been done?

Like, ok how long have we had these kinds of stainless steel? How long have we had computers and controls that could manage the landing? How long have we had the technology to computer model that landing so we can vet it before committing atoms to the problem?

When were all the pieces in place to make this happen, waiting around for someone clever to say, 'let's try it this way?'

I'm focusing on the technology here, not the organizational iterative stuff (or the finances). I guess you could do different varieties of imagination penalties, organizational would be interesting. But just the technology to do this. I have to wonder how long we've been capable of this.

Get to the outer planets with in your life time, now quite doable. And you don't even have to spend money on developing the kickstage, it's just a modded Starship after all.

first up love the video..... your usual excellent quality, but does anyone really believe the whole Starship flying to Mars thing, sending all the extra unneeded dry mass all the way to Mars and back? Just getting there and back is going to be right on the edge of whats possible, now I understand that it makes for great visuals and PR but I cannot believe that a seemingly smart guy like Mr Musk really believes that sending a Starship all the way to mars and have it land is in any way sensible. Don't get me wrong, could I see Starship trucking all the pieces of a suitable deep space vessel into orbit, stripped out cargo versions doing one way presupply trips to mars, the tanker version fuelling it on orbit and the passenger version flying the crew up to LEO hell they could even take along the press and dignitaries to wave them off, but taking the necessary mass and gear for earth reentry is just marketing guff.

Starship is an essential (and mighty impressive) part for sure, without a cheap way of launching large amounts of mass to orbit, on orbit refuelling (or fuelling) and autonomous landings (which the F9 first stage already does) for adequate presupply it's not going to be possible so bravo SpaceX for putting all the necessary pieces of the puzzle in place and they are certainly further along than almost anyone else (including NASA) but I dont think anyone can propose to really know exactly how a manned mission will look, just not a vessel going from the surface of the earth to mars and back, as visually arresting and inspirational as it is, it's just too inefficient.

Hey Tim
In more than one video you have stated that if Helium doesn't flow into fuel or lox tanks during their drain down, the turbo-pumps will suck air. There is no "air" In either tank. The pumps, rather, would suck fuel or lox vapor, or more likely a two phase mixture as tank pressure decreases. The turbo-pumps will fail due to insufficient suction head, not from sucking air; which is not in sealed tanks. Surprised this made it through peer review. Otherwise, a first rate video

Wouldn’t it make more sense to send up a downscaled super heavy booster(with a small fairing to reduce atmospheric drag)that just connects with starship in orbit orsuborbitally instead of sending a starship (referring to the upper stage not both stages) to re-fuel another starship in orbit. Starship(upper stage) has a lot of design features and tech not required when all that’s required is a “dumb” tanker. I propose a simultaneous launch of one full starship and another superheavy with a downscaled superheavy tanker “second stage”. The 2 second stages ie downscaled superheavy tanker and starship, are mated sub-orbitally so that starship doesn’t have to use its onboard fuel to reach orbit, where after the tanker will boost starship on its way to the moon or Mars. The tanker can then “coast” to the moon or do a return burn to the moon where it can be refueled for return to earth or used for other purposes. I appreciate you sticking to metric. There is absolutely no reason to use Imperial when discussing anything technical. When discussing velocity however one should use "per second" not "per hour". Many reasons. Calculations are going to result in per second answers. Delta V, for instance, is always by convention in "per second". I can tell you LEO orbital velocity is ~7.8km/sec off the top of my head but no clue what it is in km/hour. And then the conversion to per second requires division by the very un-metric number 3600. "per hour" is quasi un-scientific and in the long run more obfuscating.

I do have something to say about taking people to mars

When thinking about interplanetary missions, it would be more comprehensible if we were to master the moon first. I know that is already the idea with Artemis, but i think in order to achieve reliable and frequent missions to mars, we would need to use the moon as another launchpad - we could build the bare bones of a rocket, and still have it operational to maximise its capabilities. Without the atmosphere, we dont need chunky first stages, only fuel and a vacuum engine. This would be more ideal to set up a stable interplanetary connection - something the i believe China will master first, as they have already displayed their interests and capabilities in the moon, with Yutu 2

But by no means would this make Starship obsolete - it would serve as an initial "delivery" service for the skeleton of the international programs, sending the first crew to mars and delivering payloads to the moon for other missions

However i am only viewing this from an interplanetary perspective - Starship's Earth and moon capabilities will be insane and definitely game changing

But this is just speculation, something I've had stuck in my head for a long time

What about tetertotter style legs. The legs hide behind the skirt with the pneumatic hydraulic piston above the leg. The piston slides the leg straight down to the tetertottors fulcrum point at  the bottom of the skirt. The pivot point slides on a track with a stop at the bottom of the skirt. The piston continues to push down on its side of the tetertottor fulcrum. Swinging the other end of the tetertottor leg out from under the skirt. As the pivot point rotates, it self locks preventing the pivot point from sliding back back up once pressure is put on the foot. Then of course the hydraulic pneumatic cylinders can balance the ships orientation.

Nice work Tim, but I think you missed an interesting small angle: Vertical vs. horizontal integration.

There are major reasons why horizontal intergration works for Falcon 9, probably due the transport requirement which requires the rocket to be handled and supported while flat. This will not be the case for Starship. None of the parts will ever be horizontal while on the ground. This will simplify the structure in to a small extend as there are no requirements for strange support configurations, but it will require completely different handling facilities near the pad.
Even when the nice looking crane at the pad will be able to directly lift the booster from the landing pad onto the launch pad, there will be a day where a booster either get damaged, or needs more work done than just a polish, and needs to be moved aboutf or this. This will require a crawler-transporter type setup to at least move the boosters around, and definitely the second stages will need one.
Even if turnarounds are possible in a small number of weeks, the infrastructure required will be apollo-esque. Customers will want to have a chance to intergrate and test their payloads after installation in the starship in a near-cleanroom environment, so expect a VAB type building for the starships, and possibly a similar building for the boosters for refurbushment and rework.

What would be cool, once the super heavy goes into orbit and delivers a 'tanker', land below grade at the launch site, close the lid to be refueled.  When the tanker returns back to the launch pad, it lands on the 'lid', gets picked just a little, the lid opens up and is then sat on top of the super heavy.  It's at that time that the tanker gets refueled THROUGH the super heavy using the same inlets that were used to refuel in orbit.  The launch and landing COULD be done at the exact same pad IF the gantry / tower that is used to hold the rocket and board it goes below ground for protection. Comes up once Starship lands to load it back onto the Super Heavy.

Going to bring up a concern I've had all along that's never been addressed.
The SOUND
On takeoff the decibels will be deadly for miles.
The tip of South Padre is only 5 miles away (city is from 5 to 9 miles away) yet I've seen information that the sound might be problematic 14 mile radius away.
So far, there's no flame diverter on Super heavy launch pad. Now usually a main component of a flame diverter is the water flood system that absorbs the damaging sonic waves.
I continue to wonder what SpaceX is going to do with this problem. They've got something, I'm sure, it's just no one has said what it is.

And this is not ignoring the EVENTUAL ocean launches once Starship is fully developed.
They are building a launch complex at Boca Chica and they will not be throwing that away HUGE INVESTMENT anytime soon. So there will be launches at BC for a while.
So I see the elephant in the room but no one is talking about it.
PS- I was at STS1 (1st Shuttle launch) sitting in the NASA VIP grandstands and from miles away the sound was unbelievable. So I've had direct experience with rocket sound.
